>From: "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...>

>Have you tried placing them in in the layer of their average distance
>from the input?

Try this:  Calculate average distance to input.  Also calculate average 
distance to output.  Add the two together to get a 'total' and then position 
the node vertically based on the distance to the input as a percentage of 
the total.  Then, if it has an average distance of 3 to the input, and an 
average distance of 3 to the output, it will end up right in the middle.  If 
another has an average distance of 2 to input and 2 to output, it ends up in 
the same spot (vertically).

By the way, I'd like to try my 'attraction/repulsion' technique and see what 
comes of it.  Would someone be willing to send me their most complicated / 
difficult to render network and let me see what the technique comes up with?

-- John
